body:
Hi,

I am also facing the same issue. Did you manage to solve it?
@yzhang87 @piiswrong Let me know if further change is needed.

Generally speaking, group implementation is based one or more GEMM ( matrix multiply, one implementation way of convolution ). For example, if `group_num = 1` (default situation), then the total execution times of GEMM equals one. However, when `group_num = 2`, then the execution times of GEMM equals two.

I don't read MXNet code of low API, so Is MXNet as I said above, which shoud read low-level codes. So if you want to implement a fast depth-wise conv, maybe you should write a low-level depth-wise operator, but not python codes.
thanks for your help.
looks good to me, thanks for the patch.

Did you successfully run an android app with output library? I got following errors with version `0.10.0` built by `android-ndk-r14b` on `Mac OS X 10.12.5`.

- `cannot find "libopenblas.so"` (Solved)
- `cannot locate symbol "__emutls_v._ZN5mxnet8autograd15AutogradRuntime9is_train_E"`

Hey @thirdwing, thanks for the reply. I want to have a shared hidden representation for both the categorical and the numerical variables. Is it possible to implement this with two seperate symbols? or what do you mean exactly? 
Do you mean Symbol.group?

Edit ah do you mean the multiple loss is implemented, just not inserting two Labels? ( then it wouldnt be a Problem for the Autoencoder since the Labels are the data. )
Are you sure you have enough ram memory to train a network on cpu only ? Some network consume lot's of ram (vgg16).
The one failing Jenkin's test is about importing something from python which is not there. Not sure what I can do with that.
What "--batch-size" you used? I use --batch-size=512 then mache went out of memory, but when I turn it to 128, everything is OK.

This means that we also move linalg.h to src.  Which specific directory have you in mind? src/operator/tensor or src/common?

Concerning more operators: We (our group in Berlin/Cambridge) will likely add QR-decomposition as well (and potentially 1-2 minor ones). 
I will try to sort the planning out in 3 weeks when I'm in Palo Alto. There are even more stakeholders involved. Agree that it is currently not clear who all wants to do/have what.
Will wait with further updates for this PR until we got the prerequisite PR 274 from mshadow in.
I used a batch size of 4. The computer has 16 GB of RAM and 32 gb of swap. The graphical card is a nvidia 1070 with 8 gb of memory.
@edmBernard  My device has 16g of ram , gpu's ram is only 6G

To reproduce this:  

In a new folder:

```
git clone https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/
cd mxnet
git submodule update --init --recursive
cd amalgamation
make MIN=1
cd python
python mxnet_predict.py
```

This will throw an error.  This error does not come before mxnet version 0.9. 



--
when you say ipython kernel, you use jupyter notebook ?
The prebuilt pkgs have been updated.

@hadjipantelis The R tutorials need some revision and we are working on it.

You can find some vignettes from https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/R-package/vignettes

I just get the same error, still checking what's wrong.

The tests still failed for no reason. They all pass on my p2.xlarge instance.
@piiswrong Could you please merge this if there are no problems with the code so that I don't have to resolve conflicts every time the branch is updated?
Done
Thanks!
thanks

The .rec format is explain here http://mxnet.io/architecture/note_data_loading.html. I don't see your unknown 8bytes. 
What did you mean by "float" .rec ?
To make a .rec file you can use this script : https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/tools/im2rec.py or the [RecordIO](http://mxnet.io/api/python/io.html#mxnet.recordio.MXRecordIO) function

I think the issue is related with mxnet.symbol.FullyConnected only takes (batch_size, input_dim) as input. So, we need to reshape the outputs from RNN and labels: 
 outputs = mx.sym.Reshape(outputs, shape=(-1, 2*num_hidden))
 Y = mx.sym.Reshape(Y, shape=(-1, out_feature_size))
However, another error occurs 
ValueError: operands could not be broadcast together with shapes (16,10,10) (160,10)

ValueError: operands could not be broadcast together with shapes (16,10,10) (160,10)
is related with evaluation metric. The evaluation data also need to be reshaped. I couldn't find a better solution other than writing my own 'mse'. The working code is 
import mxnet as mx
import numpy as np
import logging

def custom_metric(label, pred):
    label = label.reshape(-1, out_feature_size)
    return np.mean((label-pred)**2)


def create_net():
    
    stack = mx.rnn.SequentialRNNCell()    
    for i in range(3):
        cell = mx.rnn.BidirectionalCell(
                mx.rnn.LSTMCell(num_hidden=num_hidden, prefix='lstm_%dl0_'%i),
                mx.rnn.LSTMCell(num_hidden=num_hidden, prefix='lstm_%dr0_'%i),
                output_prefix='bi_lstm_%d'%i)
        stack.add(cell)
    
    
    X = mx.sym.Variable('data')
    Y = mx.sym.Variable('lin_reg_label')
    
    stack.reset()
    outputs, states = stack.unroll(seq_len, inputs=X, merge_outputs=True)
    
    
    #FullyConnected: data: (batch_size, input_dim)
    outputs = mx.sym.Reshape(outputs, shape=(-1, out_feature_size))
    
    Y = mx.sym.Reshape(Y, shape=(-1, out_feature_size))
    #input_label_shapes = {'lin_reg_label':(batch_size,seq_len,out_feature_size)}
    #input_data_shapes = {'data':(batch_size,seq_len,in_feature_size)}

    fc1  = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data=outputs, name='fc1', num_hidden = num_hidden)
    act1 = mx.sym.Activation(data = fc1, name='relu1', act_type="relu")
    fc2  = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data = act1, name='fc2', num_hidden=out_feature_size)
    act2 = mx.sym.Activation(data = fc2, name='relu2', act_type="relu")
    act2 = mx.sym.Reshape(act2, shape=(-1, out_feature_size))
    #print act2.infer_shape(**input_data_shapes)
    #print Y.infer_shape(**input_label_shapes)
    
    net = mx.sym.LinearRegressionOutput(data=act2, label=Y, name="lro")
    return net


logging.getLogger().setLevel(logging.DEBUG)

seq_len=10
num_hidden = 5
in_feature_size = 30
out_feature_size = 10
batch_size = 16


#Training data
train_data = np.random.uniform(0, 1, [150, seq_len, in_feature_size])
train_label = np.random.uniform(0, 1, [150, seq_len, out_feature_size])

#Evaluation Data
eval_data = train_data
eval_label = train_label

train_iter = mx.io.NDArrayIter(train_data,train_label, batch_size, shuffle=True, label_name='lin_reg_label')
eval_iter = mx.io.NDArrayIter(eval_data, eval_label, batch_size, shuffle=False)


net = create_net()

# a = mx.viz.plot_network(net)
# a.render("example")
context = [mx.cpu(0), mx.cpu(1), mx.cpu(2)]
#context=[mx.gpu(0), mx.gpu(1), mx.gpu(2)]

model = mx.mod.Module(
    context = context,
    symbol = net,
    data_names=['data'],
    label_names = ['lin_reg_label']# network structure
)

frequent = 50
my_eval_metric = mx.metric.create(custom_metric)

#wd: weight decay for sgd
model.fit(train_iter, eval_iter,
            optimizer='sgd',
            optimizer_params={'learning_rate':0.005, 'momentum': 0.9, 'wd': 0.00001},
            num_epoch=50,
            eval_metric=my_eval_metric,
            initializer = mx.init.Xavier(factor_type="in", magnitude=2.34),
            batch_end_callback = mx.callback.Speedometer(batch_size=batch_size, frequent=frequent), #Logs training speed and evaluation metrics periodically.
            epoch_end_callback = mx.callback.do_checkpoint("test_model", 2) #test_model-0032.params
            )

score = model.score(eval_iter, my_eval_metric)
print score
This is my first time using mxnet, so, not sure if the code is correct. Could anyone verify this, thanks!! J
sorry, it's a big problem
can you give more description?

hi @Corea indeed with @edmBernard we had the same log error after adding ``libopenblas.so`` with the jniLibs list 
``java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError: dlopen failed: cannot locate symbol "__emutls_v._ZN5mxnet8autograd15AutogradRuntime9is_train_E" referenced by "/data/app/com.example.admin.mod-1/lib/arm/libmxnet_predict.so"...``

Same problem for me, using Python 2.7.13, MKL, no GPU.

Edit: the problem seems to be with alexnet. When removed from the list of tested networks, everything works fine.
as attached above, it is anaconda's ipython

I get it. the first 8 bytes is RecordIO header,which is defined in mxnet/dmlc-core/include/dmlc/recordio.h.
The next 24 bytes is image header defined in mxnet/drc/io/image_recordio.h. Is it right?
If I want to train a CNN using my non-image data. should I write a new class inherited form class DataIter and override the virtual functions? I'd like using C++.
nothing wrong happened when it was running on mxnet0.9.5
Tutorial website seems fixed(moved?), thank you.

I don't use C++ API for training.
In python [MXRecordIO](http://mxnet.io/api/python/io.html#mxnet.recordio.MXRecordIO) is used for regular data (raw data, not image). 
I find in the c_api these two functions to manage RecordIO : 
* [MXRecordIOWriterWriteRecord](http://mxnet.io/doxygen/c__api_8h.html#a0c380b6aa00446e7cb6021c8e2df75f3)
* [MXRecordIOReaderReadRecord](http://mxnet.io/doxygen/c__api_8h.html#a38e350f748967e0caa2c781a507667e4)
That's because there is additional parameter (dtype) now in the get_symbol for some networks and I forgot to give default value for it in alexnet. Posted a PR to fix it #7193

Found issue, mx.io.ImageRecordIter is in c++, cannot handle that long int as python. Index will be changed if using mx.io.ImageRecordIter to load data, i.e. index while training and validation will become different. 

Since this cannot be fixed easily, close this PR.
@ykim362 @al-rigazzi Please check with the current master.

@Ldpe2G I haven't had a chance to recompile without CUDA yet but in the meantime I moved the code to a machine with a GPU and it works as expected there now.  Is there a reason from an architectural standpoint that the package is attempting to initialize a GPU or is this a bug?

```
import mxnet.ndarray as nd
w = nd.zeros(shape=(10,2))
w[:,0] = w[:,0]
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/mxnet-0.10.0-py2.7.egg/mxnet/ndarray.py", line 405, in __getitem__
    raise ValueError('Multi-dimension indexing is not supported')
ValueError: Multi-dimension indexing is not supported
```
I see this when I try your example. What environment are you on?
Also, please use three backticks in Markdown to create code blocks for easier reading.

Mini batching is not possible using the bucketing module. 

There is a new interface that is better for tree-lstms [here](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/7022/files#diff-67f289376d3b2858314672c2a21dfb38R5) with these [tutorials](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/docs/tutorials/gluon) and [examples](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/gluon)
GPU unit test cannot be run due to functions missing in `check_numeric_gradient` for sparse tensors on GPU. GPU registration is removed for now and will be added back in the future.
@madjam Can you merge this? We discussed this fix over email yesterday.
Could you at least check whether there is an actual problem before pushing such fix? Relaxing the requirement may cause bad changes to slip through without us knowing.

I've gone through a couple of failures and the mismatch is either between ~.0999 or ~.0499. This test has been failing consistently also.

@piiswrong suggested: Increasing rtol and atol should fix it

rtol of 0.1 is equivalent to saying that we can tolerate 10% error, which seems a bit too high. https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/generated/numpy.allclose.html

On which variant does the test fail consistently?
What is the value of the variable being tested against (and failing) a 0.1 tolerance? i.e. 5000<->5000.01 is more acceptable than 0.11<->0.10

Sorry, it's not failing consistently. It's failing intermittently. When it fails, it happens on python mkl and python gpu.

Do you recommend a different tolerance, or where to start looking?
@piiswrong Is there any further issue here or is this good to merge? It seems all concerns were addressed. The CI is failing for aesthetic file length reasons so this should be fine to merge
Would it work now with gluon?

Could anyone look into this problem?

I try to find where this error come from : 
`AutogradRuntime::is_train_` is define [here](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/1bb9e45f5df2b4a283bb930a25c985b1a9b5cd82/src/ndarray/autograd.cc#L25) and [here](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/ed190957bb57abd29aca1d22d201a87fd871a272/src/ndarray/autograd.h#L110)
and it seem it's correctly include in mxnet_predict-all.cc

I only get the same error for Android compilation. 
with standard gcc and g++, I don't get any issues.
there is the same issue here : https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/7180

with nm tools to check library it find symbol `AutogradRuntime::is_train_`
on gcc : 
```
root@55b5b95994dd:~/lib/mxnet/amalgamation# nm -g ../lib/libmxnet_predict.so | grep is_train_
                 U _ZN5mxnet8autograd15AutogradRuntime9is_train_E
                 w _ZTHN5mxnet8autograd15AutogradRuntime9is_train_E
```
on arm-linux-androideabi-clang
```
root@77d4bf712ae4:~/lib/mxnet/amalgamation# nm -g ../lib/libmxnet_predict.so | grep is_train_
         w _ZTHN5mxnet8autograd15AutogradRuntime9is_train_E
         U __emutls_v._ZN5mxnet8autograd15AutogradRuntime9is_train_E
```

if it's for android it can come from android version :
https://stackoverflow.com/a/40471506/7786237
Is there a solution to this yet? I am trying to release the Module so that I can begin training a new network, but it won't release the GPU memory no matter what I do.
Is there any more information I can provide to help solve the problem?

I don't think you can compute gradient in non train mod.
The back propagation is only compute for train purpose
@edmBernard Thanks for your response! So there is no way to compute gradients while keeping dropout and batchnorm in testing mode?

I don't know for batch norm.
According to this issue https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/7200 it's seem it's not possible for dropout
(I haven't test myself)

Great job! Did you consider use the storage format proposed by http://people.csail.mit.edu/fred/tensor-compiler-techreport.pdf ? It seems to me that adding more storage formats is quite tedious (e.g. CSC, BCSR, DCSR, etc.). It will be great that we can define the storage format in a hierarchical way so future extension will be much easier.
